headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Tropical Storm Idalia Expected to Become a Hurricane, Makes Its Way Toward The Western Coast of Florida; New Screen Time Limits in China Could Become Law; U.S. Eight States Have Abolished The Tipped Minimum Wage, But Some Business Owners And Employees Don`t Want The Change. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: China`s answer, minor mode, a proposed law to order tech giants to limit children`s screen time and shut off apps. For onetired parent, the proposed rules would be a relief.

utterances.speaker: CRYSTAL GUO, MOTHER IN GUANGZHOU
utterances.sentences: This would be wonderful if it were true. There would be less anger between us.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Under the new mode, children under 18 will get a maximum of two hours on smartphones per day and will be locked outovernight. But Beijing`s top-down approach has its critics.

utterances.speaker: ANDREW COLLIER, ORIENT CAPITAL RESEARCH
utterances.sentences: The broader worry I have is that China under the current leadership is imposing a very strict culturalmoralism on their citizens, which is not going to be necessarily helpful for their personal growth or for the future of the Chinese economy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: As part of China`s broader digital crackdown, minors are already banned from gaming on weekdays. Social media apps have timelimits and some parents ship their children off to boot camps to kick internet addiction. Children are also finding ways around Beijing`s rules. This 10-year-old explains. UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translator):  Some kids use their parents` ID to log in. They never put their phones down. They`ll look at it until the battery runs out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The new guidelines order internet providers to highlight socialist and patriotic content and promote family values.UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translator):  It takes away from your time to play, exercise and read. It takes away from your time to do more interesting things.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: But her son says parents need to lead by example. It`s not easy to control myself, but adults can`t either. A battle over screentime that`s far from over. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten Second Trivia.In the U.S. what is the current federal minimum wage per hour? $5.50, $7.25, $10 or $15? Though 30 states have a higher minimum wage, the current federal minimum is $7.25. There is also something called a tipped minimum wage, meaning if a portion of your pay comes from tips, from customers, your employer can pay you less than minimum wage. The current federal tipped minimum wage is $2.13 per hour. So servers and other tipped workers can be paid $2.13 per hour by their employers with the understanding that they`ll likely earn enough money through tips to get them to at least the state`s minimum wage. But there is a movement by some U.S. states to get rid of the tipped minimum wage and eight states have abolished it. One fair wage is a group pushing for businesses to be required to raise the pay of these employees to the state`s minimum wage, plus tips. But some business owners worry this could end up hurting their bottom line, ultimately driving up prices for customers. Some employees worry that the new initiative could actually decrease their overall take-home pay. CNN`s Business and Politics Correspondent Vanessa Yurkevich is looking at the changing landscape of tipping. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) VANESSA YURKEVICH, CNN BUSINESS & POLITICS CORRESPONDENT:  This screen is stressful for many. (On camera):  Does the flip of the screen feel like a lot of pressure?

utterances.speaker: CARLY CULLEN, NEW YORKER
utterances.sentences: It does, and they give you options like 10, 15, 20, even with like Uber, Dash, and like Grubhub, all of it. Likeeverything`s tip, tip, tip.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Do you think that tipping has gotten out of control?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Tips are part of American culture, meant to be a thank you for good service. But today, more and more Americans are confronted with thequestion, would you like to add a tip?

utterances.speaker: CULLEN
utterances.sentences: It is tricky everywhere, right? Like if you`re at a coffee shop, if you`re at a hair stylist, if you`re coming out of a taxi, like I don`tknow the rules then and I often don`t know what to tip.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: A recent study found that in a high number of cases, participants who were presented with a tip screen had more negativeemotions to the payment experience than those that didn`t. And it wasn`t even a real-world scenario.

utterances.speaker: DYLAN BOSCH, NEW YORKER
utterances.sentences: Listen, you go to a coffee shop and all they do just twist around the laptop is like, why am I tipping?

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: But the small group we spoke to said more often than not, they do end up tipping.

utterances.speaker: JOSEPH GUZMEN, NEW YORKER
utterances.sentences: I put a dollar or two, I don`t mind. As long as like, you know, it`s not a lot, I just put it, because I don`t mind. Idon`t think I`m helping out, you know, other people.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: This is provisions on state, a butcher shop. There`s no table service, no cooking or serving. Yet, they`ll ask you if you`d like to tip.(On camera):  A flip screen in a butcher shop?

utterances.speaker: EMILY MINGRONE, CONNECTICUT RESTAURANT OWNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: I don`t think I`ve ever seen that before.

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: How`d you decide to do that?

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: These men and women have a knowledge base that they`re sharing and taking care to share with the guests that come through the door. Andthey`re not pressured to tip, but they want to because they`re paying for a service provided.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: This movement to get rid of the tip minimum wage, are you for it, against it?

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: I`m against it, and I think frankly it`s kind of clueless.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Eight states have abolished the tip minimum wage, which in some is as low as $2.13 an hour. The National Restaurant Association is fightingagainst it, calling it a top issue.

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: That`s money that`s going to come out of my pocket, take away from the people that aren`t getting tipped. I would need to raise myprices, which then causes pushback from the guests.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: But the group One Fair Wage is moving legislation and ballot measures to end the tip minimum wage in 25 other states, includingIllinois. (END VIDEOTAPE)
